subsection.content: On making any long service payment, the employer shall give to the person entitled to the payment a written statement indicating how the amount of the payment has been calculated. (Amended 52 of 1988 s. 13)

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: An employer who without reasonable excuse fails to comply with subsection (1) shall be guilty of an offence and shall be liable to a fine at level 3.

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: An employer who in a statement under subsection (1) includes anything which to his knowledge is false in a material particular, or recklessly includes anything which is false in a material particular shall be guilty of an offence and shall be liable to a fine at level 5. (Replaced 103 of 1995 s. 12)

subsection.content: Without prejudice to any proceedings for an offence under subsection (2)(a), if an employer fails to comply with the requirements of subsection (1), the person entitled to the payment may by notice in writing to the employer require the employer to give to the person entitled to the payment a written statement complying with those requirements within such period (not being less than 1 week beginning with the day on which the notice was given) as may be specified in the notice. (Amended 52 of 1988 s. 13)

subsection.leadIn: If, without reasonable excuse, an employer fails to comply with a notice under subsection (3) he commits an offence and is liable—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: in the case of a first conviction, to a fine at level 3; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: in the case of a second or subsequent conviction, to a fine at level 5. (Amended 24 of 1988 s. 2; 103 of 1995 s. 12)

part.name: P5C
part.heading: Supplementary Provisions to Parts VA and VB
part.sourceNote: (Part VC added 52 of 1988 s. 14. Format changes—E.R. 3 of 2017)

section.name: s31ZEA
section.heading: Application of Parts VA and VB to certain employees

subsection.content: Parts VA and VB have effect in relation to an employee engaged under a continuous contract of employment subject to subsections (2) and (3), and any enactments are to be construed accordingly.

subsection.leadIn: Parts VA and VB have effect in relation to such an employee with the modifications set out in Schedule 11 if—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the employee’s employment under the continuous contract commenced before the transition date;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the relevant date for the termination of the employment falls on or after the transition date; and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.leadIn: either or both of the following conditions are met in relation to the employee—

subparagraph.content: contributions are payable by the employer to an occupational retirement scheme because of the operation of that contract;
contributions are payable by the employer to a mandatory provident fund scheme under the Mandatory Provident Fund Schemes Ordinance (Cap. 485).

subsection.content: If the relevant date for the termination of the employee’s employment under the continuous contract precedes the transition date, then Parts VA and VB as in force immediately before the transition date continue to have effect in relation to the employee as if the amendments to this Ordinance made by the Employment and Retirement Schemes Legislation (Offsetting Arrangement) (Amendment) Ordinance 2022 (4 of 2022) had not been made.

section.name: s31ZF
section.heading: Re-employment after retirement at a specified age

subsection.leadIn: Where a continuous contract of employment specifies an age of retirement and— (Amended 4 of 2022 s. 15)

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the employee retires at that age; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the employee has been employed under that contract for not less than 5 years of service ending at the relevant date; and (Amended 74 of 1997 s. 14)

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: the long service payment to which the employee would have been entitled had the employee been dismissed at the relevant date were wholly available to be reduced under section 31Y; and (Replaced 4 of 2022 s. 15)

paragraph.name: e
paragraph.content: immediately after his retirement, the employee is re-employed by the person by whom he was employed immediately before his retirement,

subsection.continued: then for the purposes of Parts VA and VB of this Ordinance, the employment after retirement shall be regarded as a fresh employment.

part.name: P6A
part.heading: Employment Protection
part.sourceNote: (Part VIA added 75 of 1997 s. 4. Format changes—E.R. 3 of 2017)

subsection.leadIn: An employee may be granted remedies against his employer under this Part—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: where he has been employed under a continuous contract for a period of not less than 24 months ending with the relevant date and he is dismissed by the employer because the employer intends to extinguish or reduce any right, benefit or protection conferred or to be conferred upon the employee by this Ordinance;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: where he is employed under a continuous contract and the employer, without his consent and, in the absence of an express term in his contract of employment which so permits, varies the terms of his contract of employment because the employer intends to extinguish or reduce any right, benefit or protection conferred or to be conferred upon the employee by this Ordinance; or

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.leadIn: where he is dismissed by the employer other than for a valid reason within the meaning of section 32K and in contravention of—

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: section 6 of the Factories and Industrial Undertakings Ordinance (Cap. 59); or

subparagraph.name: iii
subparagraph.content: section 48 of the Employees’ Compensation Ordinance (Cap. 282),

paragraph.continued: whether or not the employer has been convicted of an offence in respect of the dismissal.

subsection.content: For the purposes of subsection (1)(a), an employee who has been dismissed by the employer shall, unless a valid reason is shown for that dismissal within the meaning of section 32K, be taken to have been so dismissed because the employer intends to extinguish or reduce any right, benefit or protection conferred or to be conferred upon the employee by this Ordinance.

For the purposes of subsection (1)(b), the variation of the terms of the contract of employment by the employer as referred to in that subsection shall, unless a valid reason is shown for that variation within the meaning of section 32K, be taken to be a variation of the terms of the contract of employment by the employer by reason that the employer intends to extinguish or reduce any right, benefit or protection conferred or to be conferred upon the employee by this Ordinance.

subsection.leadIn: For the purposes of subsection (1)(c)—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.leadIn: it shall not be necessary for an employee to show in relation to—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: subsection (1)(c)(i), that his contract of employment was terminated by reason of his exercising any of the rights vested in an employee by or by virtue of section 21B(1) or by reason of the fact of his doing any of the things mentioned in section 72B(1);

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: subsection (1)(c)(ii), that his contract of employment was terminated by reason of the fact of his doing any of the things mentioned in section 6 of the Factories and Industrial Undertakings Ordinance (Cap. 59); and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: an employee who has been dismissed by the employer shall be taken to have been dismissed without a valid reason unless a valid reason is shown for that dismissal within the meaning of section 32K.

subsection.leadIn: For the purposes of subsection (1)(c), an employee shall be entitled to remedies under this Part if and only if—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: in relation to a dismissal in contravention of section 21B(2)(b), the employee has exercised any of the rights mentioned in section 21B(1) within a period of 12 months immediately preceding such dismissal by the employer;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: in relation to a dismissal in contravention of section 72B(1), the employee has done any of the things mentioned in that section within a period of 12 months immediately preceding such dismissal by the employer;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: in relation to a dismissal in contravention of section 6 of the Factories and Industrial Undertakings Ordinance (Cap. 59), the employee has done any of the things mentioned in that section within a period of 12 months immediately preceding such dismissal by the employer.

subsection.leadIn: For the purposes of section 32A(1)(a) and subject to this Part, where an employee is dismissed because the employer intends to extinguish or reduce his right to a severance payment or to a long service payment, he shall be taken to be dismissed by his employer if, but only if—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the contract under which he is employed is terminated by the employer with or without notice or payment in lieu otherwise than in accordance with section 9;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: where under that contract he is employed for a fixed term, that term expires without being renewed under the same contract; or

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: the employee terminates that contract with or without notice or payment in lieu, in circumstances such that he is entitled to terminate it without notice or payment in lieu in accordance with section 10 by reason of the employer’s conduct.

subsection.content: Subject to subsection (1), an employee shall be taken for the purposes of section 32A(1)(a) and (c) to be dismissed by his employer when the contract under which he is employed is terminated by the employer with or without notice or payment in lieu otherwise than in accordance with section 9.

subsection.leadIn: An employee shall not be taken for the purposes of section 32A(1)(a) to be dismissed by his employer if—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: his contract of employment is renewed, or he is re-engaged by the same employer under a new contract of employment; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the renewal or re-engagement takes effect immediately on the ending of his employment under the previous contract.

subsection.content: For the purposes of the application of subsection (3) to a contract under which the employment ends on a rest day or holiday, the renewal or re-engagement shall be treated as taking effect immediately on the ending of the employment under the previous contract if it takes effect on or before the next day after that rest day or holiday.

section.name: s32C
section.heading: General exclusions from right to remedies

subsection.leadIn: An employee shall not be entitled to remedies under this Part if, not less than 7 days before the relevant date, the employer has offered to renew his contract of employment, or to re-engage him under a new contract so that—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the provisions of the contract as renewed, or of the new contract, as the case may be, would not differ from the corresponding provisions of the contract as in force immediately before the dismissal; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the renewal or re-engagement would take effect on or before the relevant date,

subsection.continued: and the employee has unreasonably refused that offer.

subsection.leadIn: An employee shall not be entitled to remedies under this Part if, not less than 7 days before the relevant date, the employer has made to him an offer in writing to renew his contract of employment, or to re-engage him under a new contract, so that in accordance with the particulars specified in the offer the provisions of the contract as renewed, or of the new contract, as the case may be, would differ, wholly or in part, from the corresponding provisions of the contract as in force immediately before the dismissal, but—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the offer constitutes an offer of suitable employment in relation to the employee;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the offer constitutes an offer of employment no less favourable to the employee than hitherto; and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: the renewal or re-engagement would take effect on or before the relevant date,

subsection.continued: and the employee has unreasonably refused that offer.

subsection.content: Where the relevant date falls on a rest day or holiday, the references in subsections (1)(b) and (2)(c) to the relevant date shall be construed as references to the next day after that rest day or holiday.

subsection.leadIn: An employee shall not be entitled to remedies under this Part by reason of dismissal where, having been given notice of the termination of his contract of employment by his employer in accordance with section 6, he leaves the service of his employer before the expiration of that notice unless he so leaves—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: with the prior consent of the employer; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: after having made a payment in lieu to the employer in accordance with section 7.

subsection.content: Subsections (1) to (3) shall not apply where an employee is dismissed in any of the circumstances mentioned in section 32A(1)(c).

subsection.leadIn: This section shall have effect where—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: a change occurs (whether by virtue of a sale or other disposition or by operation of law) in the ownership of a business for the purposes of which a person is employed, or of a part of such a business; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: in connection with that change the person by whom the employee is employed immediately before the change occurs (in this section referred to as the previous owner) terminates the employee’s contract in accordance with section 6 or 7.

subsection.content: If, by agreement with the employee, the person who immediately after the change occurs is the owner of the business or of the part of the business in question, as the case may be (in this section referred to as the new owner), renews the employee’s contract of employment (with the substitution of the new owner for the previous owner) or re-engages him under a new contract of employment, section 32B(3) shall have effect as if the renewal or re-engagement had been a renewal or re-engagement by the previous owner (without any substitution of the new owner for the previous owner).

If the new owner offers to renew the employee’s contract of employment (with the substitution of the new owner for the previous owner) or to re-engage him under a new contract of employment, but the employee refuses the offer, section 32C(1) or (2) (as the case may be) shall have effect, subject to subsection (4), in relation to that offer and refusal as it would have had effect in relation to the like offer made by the previous owner and a refusal of that offer by the employee.

subsection.leadIn: For the purposes of the operation, in accordance with subsection (3), of section 32C(1) or (2) in relation to an offer made by the new owner—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the offer shall not be treated as one whereby the provisions of the contract as renewed, or of the new contract, as the case may be, would differ from the corresponding provisions of the contract as in force immediately before the dismissal by reason only that the new owner would be substituted for the previous owner as the employer; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: no account shall be taken of that substitution in determining whether the refusal of the offer was unreasonable.

subsection.leadIn: This section shall have effect (subject to the necessary modifications) in relation to a case where—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the person by whom a business, or part of a business, is owned immediately before a change is one of the persons by whom (whether as partners, trustees or otherwise) it is owned immediately after the change; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the persons by whom a business, or part of a business, is owned immediately before a change (whether as partners, trustees or otherwise) include the person or one or more of the persons by whom it is owned immediately after the change,

subsection.continued: as this section has effect where the previous owner and the new owner are wholly different persons.

subsection.content: Nothing in this section shall be construed as requiring any variation of a contract of employment by agreement between the parties to be treated as constituting a termination of the contract.

Where the employer is a company, any reference in section 32B, 32C or 32D to renewal or re-engagement by the employer shall be construed as a reference to renewal or re-engagement by that company or by any associated company, and any reference in section 32B, 32C or 32D to an offer made by the employer shall be construed as including a reference to an offer made by an associated company.

Subsection (1) shall not affect the operation of section 32D in a case where the previous owner and the new owner are associated companies; and where that section applies, subsection (1) shall not apply.

For the purposes of this section, 2 companies shall be taken to be associated companies if one is a subsidiary of the other, or both are subsidiaries of a third company, and associated company shall be construed accordingly.

subsection.leadIn: In this section—
subsection.def: company (公司) has the meaning given by section 2(1) of the Companies Ordinance (Cap. 622);
subsidiary (附屬公司) has the meaning given by section 15 of the Companies Ordinance (Cap. 622) for the purposes of that Ordinance. (Replaced 28 of 2012 ss. 912 & 920)

def.name: RelevantDate
def.leadIn: For the purposes of and subject to this Part, relevant date (有關日期)—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: in relation to the termination of employment of an employee, has the same meaning as in section 2(1); and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: in relation to the employer varying the terms of the contract of employment of an employee, means the date on which that variation takes effect.

section.name: s32G
section.heading: Death of employer or employee
section.content: For the purposes of this Part, Part I of the Eighth Schedule shall have effect in relation to the death of an employer and Part II of that Schedule shall have effect in relation to the death of an employee.

section.name: s32I
section.heading: Claim for remedies
section.leadIn: Notwithstanding anything in this Part, an employee shall not be entitled to remedies under this Part unless—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the employee has made a claim for such remedies by notice in writing given to the employer before the end of the period of 3 months beginning with the relevant date, or within such extended period not exceeding 6 months as the Commissioner may permit; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: a question as to the right of the employee to such remedies has been made the subject of a claim filed with the Registrar of the Labour Tribunal in accordance with Part 4 of the Labour Tribunal Ordinance (Cap. 25) before the end of the period of 9 months beginning with the relevant date.

subsection.content: Subject to this section, the Labour Tribunal established under the Labour Tribunal Ordinance (Cap. 25) shall have jurisdiction to inquire into, hear and determine a claim made by an employee under this Part in accordance with this Part and with that Ordinance.

The Labour Tribunal does not have jurisdiction to inquire into, hear or determine a claim under this Part if the relevant date in respect of that claim falls more than 9 months before the date on which the claim is filed with the Registrar of the Labour Tribunal, unless the parties to the claim, by a memorandum signed by them and filed with the Registrar, have agreed that the Tribunal shall have jurisdiction. (Amended 21 of 2018 s. 3)

A claim under this Part over which the Labour Tribunal has jurisdiction may be transferred under section 10 of the Labour Tribunal Ordinance (Cap. 25) but may be so transferred only to the Court of First Instance or the District Court. (Replaced 21 of 2018 s. 3)

The Court of First Instance or the District Court may, for a claim so transferred to it, make all or any of the orders and awards provided for under sections 32N, 32O, 32P, 32PA and 32PC. (Added 21 of 2018 s. 3)
Apart from a transfer under subsection (3), neither the Court of First Instance nor the District Court has jurisdiction over a claim under this Part. (Added 21 of 2018 s. 3)

section.name: s32K
section.heading: Reasons for the dismissal or the variation of the terms of the contract of employment
section.leadIn: For the purposes of this Part, it shall be a valid reason for the employer to show that the dismissal of the employee or the variation of the terms of the contract of employment with the employee was by the reason of—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the conduct of the employee;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the capability or qualifications of the employee for performing work of the kind that the employee was employed by the employer to do; (Amended 5 of 2022 s. 4)

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: the redundancy of the employee or other genuine operational requirements of the business of the employer;

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: the fact that the employee or the employer or both of them would, in relation to the employment, be in contravention of the law, if the employee were to continue in the employment of the employer or, were to so continue without that variation of the terms of his contract of employment; or

paragraph.name: e
paragraph.content: any other reason of substance, which, in the opinion of the court or the Labour Tribunal, was sufficient cause to warrant the dismissal of the employee or the variation of the terms of that contract of employment.

section.name: s32KA
section.heading: Compliance with Cap. 599 requirement not valid reason for dismissal etc.

subsection.content: This section applies in relation to an employee who is subject to a Cap. 599 requirement, and is dismissed or has the terms of the employee’s contract of employment varied by the employer.

In determining for the purposes of this Part whether the employer has a valid reason for the dismissal of the employee or the variation of the terms of the employee’s contract of employment within the meaning of section 32K, the employee’s absence from work due to the employee’s compliance with the Cap. 599 requirement does not constitute a valid reason for the dismissal or variation.

On a claim for remedies under this Part, in determining whether or not an employer has shown that he has a valid reason for the dismissal of an employee or for the variation of the terms of the contract of employment with an employee within the meaning of section 32K, the court or the Labour Tribunal shall take into consideration the circumstances of the claim.

Without affecting the generality of subsection (1), the circumstances of a claim include the length of time that the employee has been employed under that contract of employment with the employer as compared to the length of qualifying service required for the right, benefit or protection conferred or to be conferred upon the employee by this Ordinance which is capable of being extinguished or reduced by means of the dismissal or the variation of the terms of the contract of employment.

On a claim for remedies under this Part if the court or Labour Tribunal finds that the employer has not shown a valid reason as specified under section 32K, the employer is deemed to intend to extinguish or reduce any right, benefit or protection conferred or to be conferred upon the employee by this Ordinance and the dismissal or the variation is deemed to be unreasonable and the court or Labour Tribunal may make an order under section 32N or an award of terminal payments under section 32O.

subsection.leadIn: On a claim for remedies under this Part if, in relation to the dismissal of an employee in any of the circumstances mentioned in section 32A(1)(c), the court or Labour Tribunal finds that the employer has not shown a valid reason for that dismissal within the meaning of section 32K and, upon that finding the employer, after having been given an opportunity to do so, refuses or fails to show that the dismissal is not in contravention of—

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: section 6 of the Factories and Industrial Undertakings Ordinance (Cap. 59); or

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: section 48 of the Employees’ Compensation Ordinance (Cap. 282),

subsection.continued: then the court or Labour Tribunal may make an order under section 32N or an award of terminal payments under section 32O and, in the case where the court or Labour Tribunal does not make an order under section 32N, the court or Labour Tribunal may, whether or not it has made an award of terminal payments under section 32O, make an award of compensation under and in accordance with section 32P to be payable to the employee by the employer as it considers just and appropriate in the circumstances.

subsection.content: An order or award made under this Part shall not affect the civil or criminal liability of an employer otherwise than under this Part in respect of the dismissal or the variation of the terms of the contract of employment.

Subject to this section and to section 32M, an order under this section may be an order for reinstatement (in accordance with subsections (4) and (5)) or an order for re-engagement (in accordance with subsections (6) and (7)) as the court or Labour Tribunal may decide and on terms which it considers just and appropriate in the circumstances.

The court or Labour Tribunal shall first consider whether to make an order for reinstatement, and if it decides not to make an order for reinstatement it shall then consider whether to make an order for re-engagement.

subsection.leadIn: If the court or Labour Tribunal finds that an order for reinstatement or re-engagement is appropriate—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: it must explain to the employer and the employee what order for reinstatement or re-engagement may be made; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: it must ask the employer and the employee whether they agree to the making of such an order. (Replaced 21 of 2018 s. 4)

subsection.name: 3A
subsection.content: If the employer and the employee express agreement, the court or Labour Tribunal must make an order for reinstatement or re-engagement pursuant to the agreement. (Added 21 of 2018 s. 4)

subsection.name: 3B
subsection.content: For a dismissal of an employee in any of the circumstances mentioned in section 32A(1)(c), even though only the employee expresses agreement, the court or Labour Tribunal must make an order for reinstatement or re-engagement if it finds that reinstatement or re-engagement of the employee by the employer is reasonably practicable. (Added 21 of 2018 s. 4)

subsection.name: 3C
subsection.leadIn: Before making a finding for the purposes of subsection (3B), the court or Labour Tribunal—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: must give an opportunity to the employer and the employee to present each of their cases in respect of the making of an order for reinstatement or re-engagement; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: must take into account the circumstances of the claim, including—

subparagraph.content: the circumstances of the employer and of the employee;
the circumstances surrounding the dismissal;
any difficulty that the employer might face in the reinstatement or re-engagement of the employee; and
the relationship between the employer and the employee, and between the employee and other persons with whom the employee has connection in relation to the employment. (Added 21 of 2018 s. 4)

subsection.name: 3D
subsection.leadIn: Before making a finding for the purposes of subsection (3B), the court or Labour Tribunal may, with the agreement of the employer and the employee, request the Commissioner to provide to it a report containing information that—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: relates to the circumstances of the claim; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: was obtained in connection with the conciliation held under the Labour Tribunal Ordinance (Cap. 25). (Added 21 of 2018 s. 4)

subsection.name: 3E
subsection.leadIn: On receiving the request, the Commissioner must prepare the report, seek the agreement of the employer and the employee to the contents of the report and—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: if the employer and the employee agree to the contents of the report—provide the report to the court or Labour Tribunal; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: if the employer or the employee fails to agree to the contents of the report—inform the court or Labour Tribunal of the failure and the fact that the report cannot be provided to it. (Added 21 of 2018 s. 4)

subsection.leadIn: An order for reinstatement is an order that the employer shall treat the employee in all respects as if he had not been dismissed or as if there had been no such variation of the terms of the contract of employment. On making the order, the court or Labour Tribunal must specify the terms on which the employee must be reinstated, including— (Amended 21 of 2018 s. 4)

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: any rights and privileges, including seniority and pension rights, which must be restored to the employee;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: a term to the effect that, for reckoning the employee’s existing and future entitlements under this Ordinance and the employee’s contract of employment, the continuity of the employee’s period of employment is not to be treated as broken by—

subparagraph.content: if the contract was terminated by the employer by payment in lieu of notice—the employee’s absence from work between the last date on which the employee rendered services to the employer and the date of reinstatement; or
in any other case—the employee’s absence from work between the relevant date and the date of reinstatement; (Replaced 21 of 2018 s. 4)

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: the date by which the employee must be reinstated; and (Replaced 21 of 2018 s. 4)

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: a term to the effect that, if the employee is not reinstated on the terms specified in the order by the date so specified, the employer must pay to the employee the sums mentioned in section 32NA(1) by the date specified for that purpose in the order. (Replaced 21 of 2018 s. 4)

subsection.leadIn: On the making of an order for reinstatement, if the court or Labour Tribunal considers just and appropriate in the circumstances, it may specify—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: any amount payable by the employer to the employee in respect of any arrears of pay and statutory entitlements under this Ordinance which the employee might reasonably be expected to have had but for the dismissal or the variation of the terms of the contract of employment, for the period between the relevant date and the date of reinstatement; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: any amount to be restored by the employee to the employer in respect of any statutory entitlements that the employee has been paid by the employer under this Ordinance and that the employee should not have had upon reinstatement.

subsection.leadIn: An order for re-engagement is an order that the employer must re-engage the employee in an employment on terms comparable to his original terms of the employment or in other suitable employment. On making the order, the court or Labour Tribunal must specify the terms on which the employee must be re-engaged, including— (Amended 21 of 2018 s. 4)

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the nature of the employment;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: the remuneration for the employment;

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: any rights and privileges, including seniority and pension rights, which must be restored to the employee;

paragraph.name: e
paragraph.leadIn: a term to the effect that, for reckoning the employee’s existing and future entitlements under this Ordinance and the employee’s contract of employment, the continuity of the employee’s period of employment is not to be treated as broken by—

subparagraph.content: if the contract was terminated by the employer by payment in lieu of notice—the employee’s absence from work between the last date on which the employee rendered services to the employer and the date of re-engagement; or
in any other case—the employee’s absence from work between the relevant date and the date of re-engagement; (Replaced 21 of 2018 s. 4)

paragraph.name: f
paragraph.content: the date by which the employee must be re-engaged; and (Replaced 21 of 2018 s. 4)

paragraph.name: g
paragraph.content: a term to the effect that, if the employee is not re-engaged on the terms specified in the order by the date so specified, the employer must pay to the employee the sums mentioned in section 32NA(1) by the date specified for that purpose in the order. (Replaced 21 of 2018 s. 4)

subsection.leadIn: On the making of an order for re-engagement, if the court or Labour Tribunal considers just and appropriate in the circumstances, it may specify—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: any amount payable by the employer to the employee in respect of any arrears of pay and statutory entitlements under this Ordinance which the employee might reasonably be expected to have had but for the dismissal or the variation of the terms of the contract of employment, for the period between the relevant date and the date of re-engagement; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: any amount to be restored by the employee to the employer in respect of any statutory entitlements that the employee has been paid by the employer under this Ordinance and that the employee should not have had upon re-engagement.

subsection.content: This section has effect subject to sections 32PA, 32PB and 32PC. (Added 21 of 2018 s. 4)

If the employer pays the sums mentioned in section 32NA(1) by the date specified for that purpose in an order for reinstatement or re-engagement (as varied under section 32PA or 32PC, if applicable), the employee is not entitled to enforce the other terms of the order (as so varied, if applicable). (Added 21 of 2018 s. 4)

section.name: s32NA
section.heading: Sums specified for purposes of section 32N(4)(d) and (6)(g)

subsection.leadIn: For the purposes of section 32N(4)(d) and (6)(g), the following sums are payable by the employer to the employee—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.leadIn: the sums that would have been awarded if neither an order for reinstatement nor an order for re-engagement had been made, namely—

subparagraph.content: the amount of terminal payments that would have been awarded under section 32O; and
if the employee has been dismissed in any of the circumstances mentioned in section 32A(1)(c)—the amount of compensation that would have been awarded under section 32P; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: if the employee has been dismissed in any of the circumstances mentioned in section 32A(1)(c), a sum that is the lesser of the following—

subparagraph.content: 3 times the employee’s average monthly wages as calculated in accordance with section 32NB.

subsection.content: In determining the amounts mentioned in subsection (1)(a)(i) and (ii), the court or Labour Tribunal must not take into account the sum mentioned in subsection (1)(b).
The Commissioner may, by notice published in the Gazette, amend subsection (1)(b)(i) by substituting another amount for the amount specified in that subsection.

section.name: s32NB
section.heading: Calculation of average monthly wages for section 32NA

subsection.content: This section applies in calculating an employee’s average monthly wages for the purposes of section 32NA(1)(b)(ii).

subsection.leadIn: In subsections (3), (4) and (5)—
subsection.def: wages (工資) includes a sum of money paid by an employer in respect of any of the following days—(a)a day of maternity leave, a day of paternity leave, a rest day, a sickness day, a holiday or a day of annual leave taken by the employee;(b)a day of leave taken by the employee with the agreement of the employer;(c)a normal working day on which the employee is not provided with work by the employer;(d)a day of absence from work of the employee due to temporary incapacity for which compensation is payable under section 10 of the Employees’ Compensation Ordinance (Cap. 282).

subsection.leadIn: The employee’s average monthly wages are the average monthly wages earned by the employee during—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the period of 12 months immediately before the date of termination of the contract of employment; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: if the employee has been employed by the employer for a period shorter than 12 months immediately before the date of termination of the contract of employment—the shorter period.

subsection.leadIn: The average monthly wages are to be calculated without regard to—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.leadIn: any period (excluded period) during the 12-month period or shorter period for which the employee was not paid wages or full wages because of—

subparagraph.content: any maternity leave, paternity leave, rest day, sickness day, holiday or annual leave taken by the employee;
any leave taken by the employee with the agreement of the employer;
the employee’s not being provided with work by the employer on a normal working day; or
the employee’s absence from work due to temporary incapacity for which compensation is payable under section 10 of the Employees’ Compensation Ordinance (Cap. 282); and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: any wages paid to the employee for the excluded period.

subsection.content: To avoid doubt, if the amount of the wages paid to an employee in respect of a day covered by the definition of wages in subsection (2) is only a fraction of the amount earned by the employee on a normal working day, the employee’s average monthly wages are to be calculated without regard to the wages and the day.

subsection.leadIn: Despite subsection (3), if for any reason it is impracticable to calculate an employee’s average monthly wages in the manner provided in that subsection, the amount may be calculated by reference to—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the wages earned by a person who was employed at the same work by the same employer during the period of 12 months immediately before the date of termination of the employee’s contract of employment; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: if there is no such person—the wages earned by a person who was employed in the same trade or occupation and at the same work in the same district during the period of 12 months immediately before the date of termination of the employee’s contract of employment.

subsection.content: Subject to section 32M, if no order for reinstatement or re-engagement is made under section 32N, the court or Labour Tribunal may make an award of terminal payments to be payable by the employer to the employee as it considers just and appropriate in the circumstances.

Terminal payments under this section refer to the statutory entitlements under this Ordinance that the employee has not been paid and that the employee is entitled to upon the termination of the contract of employment, or that he might reasonably be expected to be entitled to upon the termination of the contract of employment had he been allowed to continue with his original employment or original terms of the contract of employment to attain the minimum qualifying length of service required for the entitlements under this Ordinance.

subsection.leadIn: Subject to subsection (4), terminal payments include—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: any wages and other payments due to the employee under his contract of employment;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: any payment in lieu of notice payable under Part II, in the case of a dismissal without due notice;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: any end of year payment payable under Part IIA;

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: any maternity leave pay or sum payable under Part III;

paragraph.name: da
paragraph.content: any paternity leave pay payable under Part IIIA; (Added 21 of 2014 s. 7)

paragraph.name: e
paragraph.content: any severance payment payable under Part VA or any long service payment payable under Part VB;

paragraph.name: f
paragraph.content: any sickness allowance or sum payable under Part VII;

paragraph.name: g
paragraph.content: any holiday pay payable under Part VIII;

paragraph.name: h
paragraph.content: any annual leave pay payable under Part VIIIA; and

paragraph.name: i
paragraph.content: any other payments due to the employee under this Ordinance and under his contract of employment.

subsection.content: Notwithstanding that the employee has not attained the qualifying length of service required for the entitlements under this Ordinance, the court or Labour Tribunal may make an award for terminal payments under subsection (1) or (5) which shall be reckoned according to the actual length of time that the employee has been employed under that contract of employment with the employer.

For the purposes of this section, where no order for reinstatement or re-engagement is made for an unreasonable variation of the terms of the contract of employment, the court or Labour Tribunal may treat the unreasonable variation of the terms of the contract of employment as an unreasonable dismissal by the employer and make an award for terminal payments and such terminal payments should be calculated up to the last date on which the employee renders services to the employer or the date on which an award of terminal payments under this section is made by the court or Labour Tribunal, whichever is the earlier.
The respective provisions governing the calculation of the statutory entitlements shall apply to the calculation of the terminal payments. (Amended 21 of 2018 s. 6)
Sections 31I and 31IA shall apply to any severance payment paid under this section.
Sections 31Y, 31YAA and 31YA shall apply to any long service payment paid under this section.

subsection.leadIn: Subject to section 32M, the court or Labour Tribunal may, whether or not it has made an award of terminal payments under section 32O, make an award of compensation to be payable to the employee by the employer as it considers just and appropriate in the circumstances, if—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: neither order for reinstatement nor order for re-engagement under section 32N is made; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the employee is dismissed by the employer in contravention of section 15(1), 21B(2)(b), 33(4B) or 72B(1), section 6 of the Factories and Industrial Undertakings Ordinance (Cap. 59), or section 48 of the Employees’ Compensation Ordinance (Cap. 282), whether or not the employer has been convicted of the offence in respect of the dismissal.

subsection.content: In determining an award of compensation and the amount of the award of compensation under this section, the court or Labour Tribunal shall take into account the circumstances of the claim.

subsection.leadIn: Without affecting the generality of subsection (2) the circumstances of a claim include—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the circumstances of the employer and the employee;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the length of time that the employee has been employed under the contract of employment with the employer;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: the manner in which the dismissal took place;

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: any loss sustained by the employee which is attributable to the dismissal;

paragraph.name: e
paragraph.content: possibility of the employee obtaining new employment;

paragraph.name: f
paragraph.content: any contributory fault borne by the employee; and

paragraph.name: g
paragraph.content: any payments that the employee is entitled to receive in respect of the dismissal under this Ordinance, including any award of terminal payments under section 32O.

subsection.content: The amount of an award of compensation under this section shall be such amount as the court or Labour Tribunal considers just and appropriate but no such award shall exceed an amount of $150,000.
The Commissioner for Labour may amend the amount specified in subsection (4) by notice in the Gazette.

section.name: s32PA
section.heading: Alternative compliance with order for re-engagement

subsection.leadIn: For the purposes of this section—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.def: order for re-engagement (再次聘用的命令) means an order for re-engagement made under section 32N and includes such an order as varied under this section or section 32PC;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.def: successor (繼承人), in relation to an employer who employed an employee for the purposes of an undertaking or part of an undertaking, means (subject to paragraph (c)) a person who, in consequence of a change in the ownership of that undertaking or part (whether the change occurred by virtue of a sale or other disposition or by operation of law), has become the owner of that undertaking or part;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.leadIn: the definition of successor in paragraph (b) has effect (subject to the necessary modifications) in relation to a case where—

subparagraph.content: the person who owned an undertaking or part of an undertaking immediately before a change is one of the persons who own it immediately after the change (whether as partners, trustees or otherwise); or

the persons who owned an undertaking or part of an undertaking immediately before a change (whether as partners, trustees or otherwise) include the persons, or one or more of the persons, who own it immediately after the change,

paragraph.continued: as it has effect where the previous owner and the new owner are wholly different persons; and

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: associated company is to be construed in accordance with section 32E(3) and (4).

subsection.content: If the court or Labour Tribunal made an order for re-engagement (principal order) against an employer (original employer), it may, on application, order variation of the principal order to the effect that engagement of the employee by a successor or associated company of the original employer (alternative employer) is to be treated as re-engagement by the original employer in compliance with the principal order.

subsection.leadIn: An application for the purposes of subsection (2) may only be made if—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.leadIn: there is a written agreement among—

subparagraph.content: the original employer;
the employee; and
the alternative employer;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the agreement states the parties’ agreement that engagement of the employee by the alternative employer is to be treated as re-engagement in compliance with the principal order;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.leadIn: the agreement states the terms on which the alternative employer is to engage the employee in order for the engagement to be treated as re-engagement in compliance with the principal order, including—

subparagraph.content: the nature of the employment;
the remuneration for the employment;
any rights and privileges, including seniority and pension rights, that must be given to the employee;

a term to the effect that the employee’s period of employment with the original employer is to be counted as a period of employment of the employee with the alternative employer for reckoning the employee’s existing and future entitlements under this Ordinance and the employee’s contract of employment with the alternative employer; and

subparagraph.leadIn: a term to the effect that the continuity of the employee’s period of employment—

subparagraph.name: A
subparagraph.content: is not to be treated as broken by the change of employer from the original employer to the alternative employer; and

subparagraph.name: B
subparagraph.leadIn: is not to be treated as broken by—

subparagraph.content: if the employee’s contract of employment with the original employer was terminated by the original employer by payment in lieu of notice—the employee’s absence from work between the last date on which the employee rendered services to the original employer and the date of engagement of the employee by the alternative employer; or
in any other case—the employee’s absence from work between the relevant date and the date of engagement of the employee by the alternative employer; and

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: the agreement states that the parties agree that, if the alternative employer engages the employee, the terms mentioned in paragraph (c) are to form part of the employee’s contract of employment with the alternative employer.

subsection.content: The application may only be made by the employee, and must be accompanied by the agreement or a copy of the agreement.

subsection.leadIn: The application may only be made—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: not later than the date by which the employee must be re-engaged under the principal order; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: within such extended time as may be allowed by the court or Labour Tribunal.

subsection.content: An order of variation may only be made under this section if the court or Labour Tribunal is satisfied that the terms on which the alternative employer is to engage the employee, as specified in the agreement, are comparable to the terms on which the original employer is to re-engage the employee under the principal order, except the terms mentioned in section 32N(6)(f) and (g).

subsection.leadIn: An order of variation made in relation to an application under this section—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: must specify that, in order for the engagement to be treated as re-engagement in compliance with the principal order, the alternative employer must engage the employee on the terms specified in the agreement by the date specified for that purpose in the order of variation;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: must specify the legal consequences following from the alternative employer engaging the employee, as provided under section 32PB;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: must specify that, subject to paragraphs (a) and (b), the principal order remains in full force and the original employer must re-engage the employee, except that the date by which the employee must be re-engaged by the original employer is also the date mentioned in paragraph (a); and

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: must specify that the original employer must pay to the employee the sums mentioned in section 32NA(1) by the date specified for that purpose in the order of variation if, by the date mentioned in paragraph (a), the employee is not re-engaged in accordance with the order (which means neither actually so re-engaged nor treated as so re-engaged).

subsection.leadIn: Each of the following dates as specified under subsection (7) in an order of variation may be the same as or different from that date as specified in the principal order—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the date by which the employee must be engaged;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the date by which the original employer must pay the sums mentioned in section 32NA(1).

section.name: s32PB
section.heading: Legal consequences following from alternative employer engaging employee

subsection.leadIn: This section applies if—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: an order of variation is made under section 32PA to the effect that engagement of the employee by the alternative employer is to be treated as re-engagement by the original employer in compliance with the principal order; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the alternative employer engages the employee on or before the date by which the employee must be re-engaged, as specified in the order of variation,

subsection.continued: and an expression in this section that also appears in section 32PA has the same meaning as it has in that section.

subsection.content: The terms on which the alternative employer is to engage the employee, as specified under section 32PA(7)(a) in the order of variation, form part of the employee’s contract of employment with the alternative employer.

subsection.leadIn: The following applies for reckoning the employee’s existing and future entitlements under this Ordinance and the employee’s contract of employment with the alternative employer—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the employee’s period of employment with the original employer is to be counted as a period of employment of the employee with the alternative employer; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: the continuity of the employee’s period of employment—

subparagraph.content: is not to be treated as broken by the change of employer from the original employer to the alternative employer; and

subparagraph.leadIn: is not to be treated as broken by—

subparagraph.name: A
subparagraph.content: if the employee’s contract of employment with the original employer was terminated by the original employer by payment in lieu of notice—the employee’s absence from work between the last date on which the employee rendered services to the original employer and the date of engagement of the employee by the alternative employer; or

subparagraph.name: B
subparagraph.content: in any other case—the employee’s absence from work between the relevant date and the date of engagement of the employee by the alternative employer.

subsection.content: In subsection (3)(a), a reference to the employee’s period of employment with the original employer is a reference to the period of employment of the employee with the original employer that, had the original employer re-engaged the employee in accordance with the principal order, would have been counted for reckoning the employee’s existing and future entitlements under this Ordinance and the employee’s contract of employment with the original employer.
The engagement of the employee by the alternative employer is treated as re-engagement by the original employer in compliance with the principal order.

Any amount specified under section 32N(7) in the principal order as payable by the employer to the employee remains payable by the original employer to the employee. Any amount specified under that section in that order as required to be restored by the employee to the employer remains required to be restored by the employee to the original employer.

For calculating an amount specified in the principal order under section 32N(7), references in the principal order to re-engagement and to the date of re-engagement are respectively treated as references to the engagement of the employee by the alternative employer and to the date of the engagement.

section.name: s32PC
section.heading: Relief from paying sum mentioned in section 32NA(1)(b)

subsection.content: This section applies if an order for reinstatement or re-engagement is made under section 32N in respect of an employee dismissed in any of the circumstances mentioned in section 32A(1)(c), whether or not the order is varied under this section or section 32PA (which order (as so varied, if applicable) is referred to in this section as the principal order).
The employer against whom the principal order is made may apply for it to be varied to the effect that the employer is relieved from the liability to pay the sum mentioned in section 32NA(1)(b).

subsection.leadIn: An application under subsection (2) may only be made on the ground that it is no longer reasonably practicable for the employer to reinstate or re-engage the employee in accordance with the principal order—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: because of reasons attributable to the employee; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: because, since the court or Labour Tribunal last found that reinstatement or re-engagement of the employee is reasonably practicable, a change of circumstances has occurred beyond the employer’s control.

subsection.content: The application may only be made to the court, or the Labour Tribunal, that made the principal order.

subsection.leadIn: The application may only be made—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: not later than 7 days after the date by which the employee must be reinstated or re-engaged under the principal order; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: within such extended time as may be allowed by the court or Labour Tribunal.

subsection.leadIn: Before determining the application, the court or Labour Tribunal must give an opportunity to the employer and the employee to present each of their cases in respect of the application.

subsection.content: In determining the application, the court or Labour Tribunal may take into account any relevant considerations.

subsection.leadIn: The court or Labour Tribunal may—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: refuse the application;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: order that the principal order be varied to the effect that the employer be relieved, wholly or partly, from the liability to pay the sum mentioned in section 32NA(1)(b); or

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: make any order that it considers just and appropriate in the circumstances, including specifying a later date as the date by which the employee must be reinstated or re-engaged.

section.name: s32Q
section.heading: Exclusion
section.leadIn: This Part shall not apply to acts of—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: sex discrimination within the meaning of the Sex Discrimination Ordinance (Cap. 480);

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: discrimination against persons on the ground of their or their associates’ disability within the meaning of the Disability Discrimination Ordinance (Cap. 487); (Amended 7 of 2001 s. 7)

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: discrimination against persons on the ground of family status within the meaning of the Family Status Discrimination Ordinance (Cap. 527); or (Added 7 of 2001 s. 7. Amended 29 of 2008 s. 87)

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: discrimination against a person on the ground of the race of the person or his or her near relative within the meaning of the Race Discrimination Ordinance (Cap. 602). (Added 29 of 2008 s. 87)

part.name: P6
part.heading: Deductions from Wages
part.sourceNote: (Format changes—E.R. 3 of 2015)

subsection.content: No deductions shall be made by an employer from the wages of his employee or from any other sum due to the employee otherwise than in accordance with this Ordinance.

subsection.leadIn: The following deductions may be made by an employer from the wages of his employee—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.leadIn: deductions for absence from work:
Provided that—

subparagraph.content: in the case of a contract of employment under which wages are calculated on a basis of time, no such deduction shall exceed a sum proportionate to the period of time during which the employee was absent from work;

no such deduction shall be made for the purpose of defraying or partly defraying the cost of holiday pay or sickness allowance which the employer has paid or may be or may become liable to pay to the employee; (Replaced 39 of 1973 s. 4)

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: deductions for damage to or loss of goods, equipment or property belonging to or in the possession or control of the employer or expressly entrusted to an employee for custody, or for loss of money for which an employee is required to account, where such damage or loss is directly attributable to his neglect or default:
Provided that—

subparagraph.content: the total amount recoverable by deduction in any one case shall not exceed the equivalent in value of the damage or loss suffered by the employer or $300, whichever is the less; and
the total of such deductions in any one wage period shall not exceed one quarter of the wages payable to the employee in respect of that wage period;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: deductions in respect of meals supplied by the employer at the request of the employee not exceeding the cost to the employer of such meals including expenses of production and service;

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: deduction for accommodation provided by the employer for the employee or his family made in respect of the period such accommodation has been in the occupation of the employee or his family;

paragraph.name: e
paragraph.leadIn: deductions for the recovery of any advance or over-payment of wages made by the employer to the employee:
Provided that—

subparagraph.content: except with the approval in writing of the Commissioner, no such deductions shall be made by way of discount, interest or any similar charge in consideration of such advance or over-payment; and
the total of such deductions in any one wage period shall not exceed one quarter of the wages payable to the employee in respect of that wage period;

paragraph.name: f
paragraph.content: deductions, with the written consent of an employee, for the recovery of any loan made by the employer to the employee;

paragraph.name: g
paragraph.content: deductions made at the request in writing of the employee in respect of contributions to be paid by him through the employer for the purpose of any medical benefit scheme, superannuation scheme, retirement scheme or thrift scheme lawfully established for the benefit of the employee or his dependants; (Amended 41 of 1990 s. 17)

paragraph.name: ga
paragraph.content: deductions permitted by section 15L(4); (Added 21 of 2014 s. 8)

paragraph.name: h
paragraph.content: deductions which are required or authorized under any enactment to be made from the wages of an employee;

other deductions made at the request in writing of the employee and with the approval of the Commissioner, which may be signified in respect of any particular case in writing or in general by notice in the Gazette.

subsection.content: Except with the approval in writing of the Commissioner, the total of all deductions, excluding deductions in respect of absence from work or any deduction pursuant to an attachment order made under section 20(1) of the Guardianship of Minors Ordinance (Cap. 13), section 9A(1) of the Separation and Maintenance Orders Ordinance (Cap. 16) or section 28(1) of the Matrimonial Proceedings and Property Ordinance (Cap. 192), made under this section from the wages of an employee in any one wage period shall not exceed one half of the wages payable to the employee in respect of the wage period. (Amended 69 of 1997 s. 34)

Nothing in this section shall be construed as preventing an employer from paying to an employee at any time before the due date the amount of wages and other remuneration proportionate to work done and adjusting any amount so paid against the total amount payable at the end of the wage period.

part.name: P7
part.heading: Sickness Allowance
part.sourceNote: (Part VII added 39 of 1973 s. 5. Format changes—E.R. 2 of 2012)

subsection.content: An employee who has been employed by his employer under a continuous contract for a period of 1 month or more immediately preceding a sickness day shall be paid by his employer sickness allowance in accordance with this section and section 35. (Amended 1 of 1977 s. 2; 48 of 1984 s. 14)

subsection.leadIn: Subject to subsection (2A), an entitlement to sickness allowance shall accrue at the rate of—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: 2 paid sickness days for each completed month of the employee’s employment under the continuous contract with his employer during the first 12 months of such employment; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: 4 paid sickness days for each such month thereafter,

subsection.continued: and may be accumulated from time to time up to a maximum of 120 paid sickness days. (Replaced 57 of 1983 s. 5)

subsection.name: 2A
subsection.content: In the case of an employee who has been employed by his employer under a continuous contract for a period of 1 month or more immediately preceding the commencement* of the Employment (Amendment) Ordinance 1983 (57 of 1983), the employee’s entitlement to sickness allowance shall, with effect from and without prejudice to the entitlement to sickness allowance accrued at such commencement, accrue at the rate prescribed by subsection (2) as amended by that Ordinance, and his employment for part of a month (if any) at such commencement shall be taken into account in calculating his entitlement to sickness allowance under and at the rate prescribed by that subsection. (Added 57 of 1983 s. 5)
Subject to subsection (3C), an employee who takes less than 4 consecutive days as sickness days shall not be entitled to be paid sickness allowance in respect thereof. (Amended 22 of 1981 s. 7)

subsection.name: 3A
subsection.content: Where a female employee who is pregnant or who has given birth to a child and who is required to attend a medical examination in relation to her pregnancy or post confinement medical treatment, any day on which she is absent from work for such examination or treatment shall be a sickness day. (Added 22 of 1981 s. 7)

subsection.name: 3B
subsection.content: Where a female employee suffers a miscarriage, any day on which she is absent from work by reason of such miscarriage shall be a sickness day. (Added 22 of 1981 s. 7)

subsection.name: 3C
subsection.content: A female employee who has an entitlement to a sickness allowance under this section shall, notwithstanding subsection (3), be paid sickness allowance for every sickness day under subsection (3A) or (3B), and subsections (4), (4A), (5), (5A) and (7) shall apply to any such sickness day and sickness allowance in respect thereof. (Added 22 of 1981 s. 7. Amended 57 of 1983 s. 5)

Subject to subsections (5) and (5A), an employee who takes 4 or more consecutive days as sickness days shall be entitled to be paid sickness allowance for the total number of sickness days taken by him, but not exceeding the number of paid sickness days accumulated by him, under subsections (2) and (2A), immediately before the commencement of the sickness days taken. (Replaced 57 of 1983 s. 5)

subsection.name: 4A
subsection.content: The number of sickness days in respect of which an employee has been paid sickness allowance under subsection (4) shall be deducted in accordance with section 37(1B) from the total number of paid sickness days accumulated by him. (Added 57 of 1983 s. 5)

subsection.name: 4B
subsection.content: Subject to subsection (4BAA), an employer shall not terminate a contract of employment of an employee otherwise than in accordance with section 9 on any sickness day taken by the employee in respect of which sickness allowance is payable under this section. (Replaced 7 of 2001 s. 8)

subsection.name: 4BAAA
subsection.leadIn: For the purposes of subsections (4BA)(b), (4BAAB) and (4BAAC), wages (工資) includes any sum paid by an employer in respect of—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: a day of maternity leave, a day of paternity leave, a rest day, a sickness day, a holiday or a day of annual leave taken by the employee; (Amended 21 of 2014 s. 9)

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: a day of leave taken by the employee with the agreement of his employer;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: a normal working day on which the employee is not provided with work;

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: a day of absence from work of the employee due to temporary incapacity for which compensation is payable under section 10 of the Employees’ Compensation Ordinance (Cap. 282). (Added 7 of 2007 s. 9)

subsection.name: 4BA
subsection.leadIn: An employer who contravenes subsection (4B) shall be liable to pay to the dismissed employee—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the sum which would have been payable if the contract had been terminated by the employer under section 7; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: a further sum equivalent to 7 times the daily average of the wages earned by the employee during—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: the period of 12 months immediately before the date of termination of the contract of employment; or

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: if the employee has been employed by the employer for a period shorter than 12 months immediately before the date of termination of the contract, the shorter period. (Replaced 7 of 2007 s. 9)

subsection.name: 4BAAB
subsection.leadIn: In calculating the daily average of the wages earned by an employee during the period of 12 months or the shorter period—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.leadIn: any period therein for which the employee was not paid his wages or full wages by reason of—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: any maternity leave, paternity leave, rest day, sickness day, holiday or annual leave taken by the employee; (Amended 21 of 2014 s. 9)

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: any leave taken by the employee with the agreement of his employer;

subparagraph.name: iii
subparagraph.content: his not being provided by his employer with work on any normal working day; or

subparagraph.name: iv
subparagraph.content: his absence from work due to temporary incapacity for which compensation is payable under section 10 of the Employees’ Compensation Ordinance (Cap. 282); and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: any wages paid to him for the period referred to in paragraph (a),

subsection.continued: are to be disregarded. (Added 7 of 2007 s. 9)

subsection.name: 4BAAC
subsection.content: For the avoidance of doubt, if the amount of the wages paid to an employee in respect of a day specified in subsection (4BAAA) is only a fraction of the amount earned by the employee on a normal working day, the wages and the day are to be disregarded in accordance with subsection (4BAAB). (Added 7 of 2007 s. 9)

subsection.name: 4BAAD
subsection.content: Despite subsection (4BA)(b), if for any reason it is impracticable to calculate the daily average of the wages earned by an employee in the manner provided in that subsection, the amount may be calculated by reference to the wages earned by a person who was employed at the same work by the same employer during the period of 12 months immediately before the date of termination of the employee’s contract of employment, or, if there is no such person, by a person who was employed in the same trade or occupation and at the same work in the same district during the period of 12 months immediately before the date of termination of the employee’s contract of employment. (Added 7 of 2007 s. 9)

subsection.name: 4BAA
subsection.leadIn: An employer who terminates the continuous contract of employment of an employee on any sickness day taken by the employee in respect of which sickness allowance is payable under this section shall be taken for the purposes of subsection (4B) to terminate the contract otherwise than in accordance with section 9—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: unless the contrary is proved; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: subject to subsection (4BAB), unless the employer proves that—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: he purported to terminate the contract in accordance with that section; and

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: at the time of such termination, he reasonably believed that he had a ground to do so. (Added 7 of 2001 s. 8)

subsection.name: 4BAB
subsection.content: Subsection (4BAA)(b) shall not apply in the case of civil proceedings. (Added 7 of 2001 s. 8)

subsection.name: 4BB
subsection.content: Any employer who contravenes subsection (4B) shall be guilty of an offence and shall be liable on conviction to a fine at level 6. (Replaced 7 of 2001 s. 8)

subsection.name: 4C
subsection.content: Where an employer terminates a contract of employment of an employee on any sickness day taken by the employee, the employer shall, notwithstanding the termination of the contract of employment, pay to the employee sickness allowance for the total number of sickness days in respect of which the employee would have been entitled to be paid sickness allowance under subsection (4), and subsections (5), (5A) and (7) shall apply to any such sickness day and sickness allowance in respect thereof as if the contract of employment had not been terminated. (Added 57 of 1983 s. 5)

subsection.leadIn: An employer shall not be liable to pay sickness allowance to an employee in respect of any sickness day—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: subject to paragraph (ab) and subsections (5A) and (5B), unless such day is a day specified in the appropriate medical certificate as a day on which, in the opinion of the registered medical practitioner, registered Chinese medicine practitioner or registered dentist who issued the certificate, the employee was, is or will be, as the case may be, unfit for work on account of sickness or injury; (Amended 57 of 1983 s. 5; 5 of 1995 s. 9; 16 of 2006 s. 7; 13 of 2020 s. 10; 5 of 2022 s. 7)

paragraph.name: ab
paragraph.content: (if the employee is absent from work due to the employee’s compliance with a Cap. 599 requirement) subject to subsection (8), unless such day is shown, by any of the means specified in Part 2 of Schedule 12, to be a day on which the employee is subject to the Cap. 599 requirement; (Added 5 of 2022 s. 7)

paragraph.name: ac
b
paragraph.content: if, where the employer is operating a recognized scheme of medical treatment, the employee, at any time during the sickness or injury, unless he is a patient in a hospital, refuses without reasonable excuse to submit himself for treatment under the scheme; (Amended 57 of 1983 s. 5; 5 of 1995 s. 9; 16 of 2006 s. 7)

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.leadIn: if, where the employer is operating a recognized scheme of medical treatment, the employee, having submitted himself for treatment by the registered medical practitioner, registered Chinese medicine practitioner or registered dentist engaged by the employer for the purposes of the scheme or being a patient in a hospital, at any time during the sickness or injury, without reasonable excuse, disregards— (Amended 16 of 2006 s. 7)

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: the advice of such medical practitioner, Chinese medicine practitioner or dentist; or

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: the advice of the registered medical practitioner, registered Chinese medicine practitioner or registered dentist who is attending him in the hospital; (Amended 57 of 1983 s. 5; 5 of 1995 s. 9; 16 of 2006 s. 7)

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: if the unfitness for work of the employee is caused by his serious and wilful misconduct;

paragraph.name: e
paragraph.content: if the unfitness for work of the employee is on account of an injury or occupational disease in respect of which compensation is payable in accordance with the Employees’ Compensation Ordinance (Cap. 282);

paragraph.name: f
paragraph.content: in respect of which the employee has received holiday pay.

subsection.name: 5AA
subsection.leadIn: Where a medical certificate issued for the purposes of subsection (5)—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: is issued by a registered medical practitioner, subsection (5)(b) applies only if the recognized scheme of medical treatment operated by the employer covers medical treatment given by a registered medical practitioner;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: is issued by a registered Chinese medicine practitioner, subsection (5)(b) applies only if the recognized scheme of medical treatment operated by the employer covers medical treatment given by a registered Chinese medicine practitioner; or

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: is issued by a registered dentist, subsection (5)(b) applies only if the recognized scheme of medical treatment operated by the employer covers medical treatment given by a registered dentist. (Added 16 of 2006 s. 7)

subsection.name: 5A
subsection.content: Where an employee takes paid sickness days (other than any sickness day that falls within paragraph (b) of the definition of sickness day in section 2(1)) entered in category 2 of the record kept in respect of him under section 37(1A), he shall, if so required by his employer, produce to the employer, in respect of each such sickness day, a medical certificate that is issued by a registered medical practitioner, registered Chinese medicine practitioner or registered dentist attending the employee as an out-patient or in-patient in a hospital. (Added 57 of 1983 s. 5. Amended 5 of 1995 s. 9; 16 of 2006 s. 7; 5 of 2022 s. 7)

subsection.name: 5B
subsection.content: For a sickness day under subsection (3A) on which a female employee attends a medical examination in relation to her pregnancy, the employer is liable to pay sickness allowance for that day if the employee produces, in relation to the examination, a certificate of attendance described in section 33A. (Added 13 of 2020 s. 10)

subsection.leadIn: For the purposes of this section—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.def: the expression hospital (醫院) means a hospital or specialist clinic maintained by the Government, a military hospital, a public hospital within the meaning of the Hospital Authority Ordinance (Cap. 113), The Chinese Medicine Hospital of Hong Kong (as defined by section 2(5) of The Chinese Medicine Hospital of Hong Kong Ordinance (15 of 2025)) or a hospital in respect of which a person is licensed under the Private Healthcare Facilities Ordinance (Cap. 633); (Amended 81 of 1991 s. 2; 2 of 2012 s. 3; 34 of 2018 s. 152 and E.R. 5 of 2018; 15 of 2025 s. 3)

def.name: AppropriateMedicalCertificate
def.leadIn: in subsection (5)(a), the expression appropriate medical certificate (適當的醫生證明書) means—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.leadIn: where, on the day on which the certificate is issued, the employer is operating a recognized scheme of medical treatment—

subparagraph.name: A
B
C
D
E
subparagraph.content: (if the employee refuses with reasonable excuse to submit himself for treatment under the scheme) a certificate issued by any registered medical practitioner, registered Chinese medicine practitioner or registered dentist; (Replaced 16 of 2006 s. 7)

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: where, on the day on which the certificate is issued, the employee is a patient in a hospital, a certificate issued by the registered medical practitioner, registered Chinese medicine practitioner or registered dentist attending the employee in the hospital; or

subparagraph.name: iii
subparagraph.content: in any other cases, a certificate issued by any registered medical practitioner, registered Chinese medicine practitioner or registered dentist. (Replaced 57 of 1983 s. 5. Amended 5 of 1995 s. 9; 16 of 2006 s. 7)
